question_answers.question: Open Ended Submission
question_answers.answer:
1. In the first week, I‚Äôd want to get a solid grasp of the current user experience by speaking directly with the end users to understand ongoing pain points. I‚Äôd also like to jump in on a smaller, high-impact feature that‚Äôs part of the current roadmap-something that can be shipped quickly and deliver immediate value. I‚Äôm a firm believer in learning by doing, so tackling a task that touches different parts of the stack would help me get up to speed with the codebase and start contributing right away.

2. At Edvo, we built a real-time collaborative canvas tool, and a big part of the challenge was creating an interface that felt seamless for different workflows. I noticed during user testing that people struggled with discovering and finding the right tool at the right time, so I proposed a context-aware action menu that dynamically displayed the most relevant actions/shortcuts based on what the user clicked/selected. This approach reduced the cognitive load and made the experience feel much more ‚Äòmagical‚Äô for users. It‚Äôs an example where paying attention to user behavior and striving for better user experience really paid off.

3. I‚Äôm really driven by the opportunity to help people and make difficult or complex processes more accessible and seamless. Recruiting can be overwhelming for everyone, and going through it myself, I definitely feel there are areas for better user empathy. As such, I find it rewarding to create products that make users' workflows or experience smoother and more human-centered. Being able to have real, meaningful impact on users, is what ultimately drives me to continue to work on innovative products.

While at my consulting job, I was tasked with creating a smart widget that would live in Ascension Healthcare‚Äôs intranet portal, capable of pulling information about patients and dynamically displaying it on-screen such that employees could filter/sort/search through the patient information. Due to the limits on Ascension‚Äôs intranet portal, only 6 packages could be used in the application to be able to be compiled and uploaded to the LumApps intranet portal that they used. With this limitation in mind, I proposed designs to the client and built out the frontend and backend of the widget, which was essentially Google Cloud Functions that would retrieve data from the existing Workspace files that contained the patient data. Although I didn‚Äôt create my own backend for this client application, I had to design and propose a secure way for the widget to access the Google Cloud Functions in the GCP backend. Though I didn‚Äôt have any experience with cloud security, I learnt the best practices and created a system of two serverless functions, one that would be accessible to only the LumApps widget to create a token given a certain Client ID & Secret and another one that would use this token to access the Workspace files containing the patient data. After multiple meetings with the cloud security team discussing this implementation, it was cleared and approved.

At Uber, the pursuit of reimagination is never finished, never stops, and is always just beginning.

company.name: Trusted Health
company.one_liner: (em)Powering the Healthcare Workforce
company.description:
Trusted, Inc. is the leading labor marketplace and workforce management platform for the healthcare industry. 

The company was founded in 2017 with a focus on the largest profession in healthcare: nursing. Since then, they've taken a process that has been dominated by recruiters and phone calls and turned that into a a fully digital experience, connecting nurses directly to job opportunities and facilitating everything that needs to happen in between‚Äîincluding handling benefits, payroll, onboarding, and compliance. Their platform also provides full employer-of-record services for employers in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. 
 
In 2020, they launched their proprietary staffing platform, Works (www.works.ai). Works helps hospitals meet one of their single biggest challenges: ensuring that every shift gets filled in an environment where both demand for healthcare services and the cost of labor are increasing exponentially. With Works, facilities can create their own on-demand nursing workforce and access one source of truth for all of their clinical workforce needs, from sourcing and onboarding to ongoing compliance. With predictive insights and recommendations, Works helps hospitals easily react to fluctuations in demand, while its staffing marketplace creates competition to fill open job requisitions with high-quality, active talent from a pre-onboarded network of talent suppliers. 
 
The company has support from top institutional investors such as Craft Ventures, Felicis Ventures, StepStone Group and Founder Collective, as well as healthcare innovators like Texas Medical Center, Mercy Health, Intermountain Ventures, Town Hall Ventures, and Healthbox. In 2020, they were featured on Forbes Next Billion Dollar Startups List.

question_answers.question: Additional Info
question_answers.answer:
Project: 0-1 Scalable RAG Pipeline + Novel RAG Improvements 

Timeline: Aug 2024 - Oct 2024 

Author: M Sarosh Khan 

I am a Staff AI Engineer who used to be a Senior Software Engineer/tech lead operating with an academic background in Machine Learning. Most recently, I got to sample that entire skillset and put it into production for paying customers. 

- Built our RAG System/pipeline 

- Built a backend in AWS/Pulumi then seamlessly wired it into our existing app - Solved relevant open ended research questions around RAG 

- Scaled those solutions inside of the backend I created 

- Battle tested with real customers 

- Backpropgated feedback to the research progression and re-integrated as needed This document serves as a showcase, but not a detailed technical walkthrough. 

Problem Space 

Second.dev is an enterprise platform for migrating codebases between two arbitrary tech stacks. Examples include AngularJS -> React, Python -> Kotlin, Terraform -> Crossplane. The migrations are flexible, and do not enforce the architecture of the starting codebase. It's more akin to getting LLMs to use the context of one codebase to produce a complete app satisfying the same features. 

On average, starting codebases had 15,000+ lines of code 

Needs/Challenges 

- Guard rails: a mistake made earlier in the generation propogates to future generations. - Context ordering: RAG and variants of RAG do not account for information ordering ‚Äì a file needs to be have its dependencies implemented before being implemented itself. - Cost: the token size of enterprise codebases is an order of magnitude greater than the token limit for state of the art models. 

- Nuance: Language servers do not automatically render strict supersets of dependencies, they are also not always available (e.g Angular JS). 

- Automatic Bug Fixing: Catch errors as they spawn, find where they originate, and solve them mid-migration.

- Quality Assurance: Ensure tests passing in the original codebase are migrated and still passing in the new codebase. 

- Zero-Shot: One codebase topology does not differentiably inform another ‚Äì customers needed an automatic bespoke solution on command. 

Even with these challenges, Second was able to complete migrations with 95% accuracy ‚Äì 5% of the lines written by the AI system needed modification to 100% finalize a migration by leveraging the pipeline I owned/created. 

Solution 

Foremost, RAG requires that the 

embedding of an incoming query naturally 

embeds closer to an answer to that query. 

Also, in the context of codebases, two files 

which embed more closely are only sparsely 

more likely to depend on each other. From an 

engineering perspective, we needed an 

efficient extensible RAG system, but from a 

Machine Learning perspective we needed to 

solve these shortcomings in a cost effective 

manner. Existing attempts at this solution (e.g GraphRAG, RAGChain, Prompt-RAG, etc) were meant for static document clusters, when our customer documents were dynamic. 

We represented this as a semi-supervised learning problem 

and implemented a Knowledge Graph representation of the 

document store. This knowledge graph representation was 

then queried topologically to render a traversal order for a 

long-context LLM chain of thought approach1. Interestingly, 

when scoring methods for community clusers were applied to 

this approach, it had the effect of organizing the data 

perfectly sequentially.2 

1 Blue edges are learned on-demand, red edges are classic RAG sastisfying an optimal threshold2 E.g, GraphRAG and other such alternatives don't end up with adjacent communities.
